content: The Act may be cited as the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act of 2001" and includes findings and purposes. The Arabia Mountain area contains natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources that represent the heritage of the United States. Managing these resources through partnerships between public and private entities is the best approach. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve in DeKalb County, Georgia is a 535-acre park. The best approach for managing the resources of the Arabia Mountain area is through partnerships between public and private entities. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve in DeKalb County, Georgia protects granite outcrop ecosystems, wetlands, and federally-protected plant species. Panola Mountain, a national natural landmark, is located in the 860-acre Panola Mountain State Conservation Park. The Panola Mountain State Conservation Park in DeKalb County, Georgia protects granite outcrop ecosystems, wetlands, and pine and oak forests, including federally-protected plant species. Panola Mountain is a rare example of a pristine granite outcrop, while the Miners Creek Preserve contains evidence of early human activity. The city of Lithonia, Georgia, along with Arabia Mountain and Stone Mountain, have sites showcasing historical significance. The Miners Creek Preserve at Lithonia, Georgia, contains evidence of early human activity. Lithonia, along with Arabia Mountain and Stone Mountain, showcases the history of granite mining in Georgia. Klondike is eligible for National Historic District designation, and Lithonia has 2 structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The history of granite mining in Georgia and its impact on the United States is highlighted. Klondike is eligible for National Historic District designation, and Lithonia has 2 structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, and promote natural, cultural, and historical resources in the area including Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, and Miners Creek. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, promote, interpret, and make available natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources in the area including Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, Miners Creek, and other significant sites and communities. It also assists Georgia and the counties of DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry in developing and implementing a cultural, historical, and land resource management program. The Act aims to assist Georgia and the counties of DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry in developing and implementing a program to protect, enhance, and interpret significant resources within the heritage area, including Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, and Miners Creek. The Act defines key terms such as "heritage area," "management entity," "management plan," "Secretary," and "State" in relation to the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area established to protect and enhance significant resources in Georgia. SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA. Established the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in the State, consisting of certain parcels of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. The map depicting the boundaries is available for public inspection. The Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance is designated as the management entity. SEC. 5. AUTHORITIES AND DUTIES OF THE MANAGEMENT ENTITY. The management entity has authorities to make grants, enter agreements, hire staff, and enter contracts. They are responsible for developing and submitting the management plan to the Secretary. The management entity is responsible for developing and submitting a management plan to the Secretary, considering diverse interests within the heritage area. Priority is given to implementing actions outlined in the plan, including assisting government and nonprofit entities. The management entity prioritizes implementing actions from the management plan, including assisting government and nonprofit organizations in preserving resources and encouraging land use policies consistent with the heritage area goals. The management entity assists government and nonprofit organizations in preserving resources and encourages land use policies consistent with the heritage area goals. Public meetings are conducted quarterly, and an annual report is required for years with Federal funds. The management entity conducts quarterly public meetings and submits an annual report to the Secretary detailing accomplishments, expenses, and income. The entity must also make financial records available for audit. The management entity must submit an annual report to the Secretary outlining accomplishments, expenses, and income. They are also required to make all financial records available for audit. The management entity must provide all records related to the expenditure of Federal funds for audit. Federal funds cannot be used to acquire real property. The management entity must provide all records related to the expenditure of Federal funds for audit and cannot use these funds to acquire real property. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept from the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Feasibility Study. This plan should involve residents, public agencies, and private organizations in the area, taking into consideration State and local plans. The management plan for the heritage area, based on the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Feasibility Study, must consider State and local plans, involve residents, public agencies, and private organizations, and include an inventory of resources related to the heritage area's purposes. The management plan for the heritage area must include an inventory of resources, such as property related to the area's purposes and cultural landscapes, along with provisions for protection and interpretation. The management plan for the heritage area should include an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and interpretation of resources, an interpretation plan, and a program for implementation. The management plan for the heritage area should include an interpretation plan, a program for implementation, actions by various entities to protect resources, funding sources, and evaluation of the management entity. The management plan for the heritage area should include actions by government, private organizations, and public-private partnerships to protect resources, identification of funding sources, and evaluation of the management entity. The management entity must submit the plan to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The management entity must submit the management plan to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Failure to submit the plan will result in a halt of additional funding until a plan is submitted. If a management plan is not submitted by the specified date, additional funding will be withheld until a plan is submitted. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the management plan within 90 days of receiving it. If the plan is disapproved, it must be revised. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the management plan within 90 days of receiving it. If disapproved, revisions must be made as per the Secretary's recommendations. The Secretary must advise the management entity of reasons for disapproval, make recommendations for revisions, and allow for resubmission of the management plan within 90 days. After approval by the Secretary, the management entity can submit revisions to the management plan. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the revision within 90 days. After approval by the Secretary, the management entity shall periodically review and submit recommendations for any revisions to the management plan for approval. No funds under this Act shall be used to implement any proposed revisions. The management entity must seek approval from the Secretary for any revisions to the management plan before implementing them with funds from this Act. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to heritage areas for developing and implementing management plans, prioritizing conservation and educational opportunities. Authorization of $10,000,000 for the Act, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. Federal share capped at 50%. Secretary's grant authority ends on September 30, 2016.
